metadata.name: Ersbla #638
metadata.description:
Ersbla is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022. 

It is the third entry in a series of abstract generative experiments inspired by the graphic and textile work of Anni and Josef Albers. As a follow-up to the 'Sabler' and 'Lebras' collections, 'Ersbla' produces textile effects using a combination of thousands of tiny dots arranged on variable grids, resulting in a wide variety of unique Bauhaus-inspired compositions in a variety of palettes.

Press 'S' to save a high-resolution 2400 x 3396 px image in PNG format.

Depending on the density of your output, please allow up to a few seconds for your edition to generate.

metadata.name: Emotional Shell #366
metadata.description:
Manual Dutch Auction (DA): 72 · 54 · 40 · 30 · 24 · 20 every 8 minutes.
Auction will stop changing price when non-reserves are fully minted, and then drop one price tier.

---------

The feeling of being human – with all of its intricate hopes, struggles, and fleeting emotions – seems so unique that we assume artificial intelligence could never replicate our experience. And while we devise systems for solving unfathomably complex problems, generating algorithmic creativity, and unlocking regenerative biological possibilities, we simultaneously cling to the power and originality of emotional feeling – believing it to be the irreplaceable source of what makes us human.

If the body is our shell for emotion and soul, can an artificial humanoid be another vessel for these thoughts and feelings – for human essence itself? If our ‘soul’ is the last stand between us and the machines, what happens when the soul becomes transferable? That we may see answers to these questions looks more real every year, and is perhaps a little frightening. 

Emotional Shell uses introspective portraits of future selves to question what it means to be human, when the people around us are no longer human.

---------

Warning: This piece is GPU intensive, it may not render on lower end devices.

Press 1-3 to select from low, medium, and high quality settings
Press 'S' to save the image at the current scale
Press 'H' to save the image at 2400px resolution

Created with Three.js
For third party license information, please see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt

---------

TENDER x wwatkns
August 2022

metadata.name: Abstract Life #5
metadata.description:
The concept of organic, obtained from living systems, is said to be an effect that, like a plant and a living being, has grown in a completely dynamic manner in different degrees, and no factor except vital forces has prevented its growth. Organic creation is an example of this type. Léonard de Vinci believed in nature; he wrote, "Painting is a child of nature" in his opinion, art should be compatible with nature. His public image of creativity was "innovation while maintaining fidelity" to nature. According to Michelangelo, the form the artist gives to the materials is in the artist's mind and the materials themselves. Therefore, the artist is always in a metaphysical struggle with the form and secrets of nature. This is a revelatory process through which the artist discovers the mass of paper already hidden in his mind and the materials. As an architect, I tried to create this work while paying attention to the structuralism of shapes and forms in creation, inspired by the colors in nature and my experience in painting and illustration.

To spread the vibe of my beautiful community, minters will own 50% of royalty on each secondary sale.
Eighteen different color palettes and three different borders are used in this artwork.
Made in p5js
Created August 2022
Artist: @ChistaAi

metadata.name: Morphing Convictions #5
metadata.description:
Everyday we move on by relying on our convictions. Their immutability often helps us take decisions or take shelter but can sometimes clash with the unknown, the different and the new. They can then crack, crumble and mutate. To change your convictions means changing the kind of person you want to be. It means changing your self-identity. And that is not just hard, it is scary. And beautiful.

Morphing Convictions is a piece that exists through two kind of outputs : Posters and Scenes. Posters are focusing on the contemplation of details and movements of a morphing conviction while the Scenes are interactive little worlds where you can explore a conviction in it's environment.

Please open in live mode to enjoy a much better experience.

Controls :

Posters & Scenes
• Click anywhere to enable audio.
• Press M to toggle mute.
• Press F to toggle the fullscreen mode.
• Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

Scenes only
• Drag and scroll to rotate and zoom.
• Click on objects, some might react.

———————

Morphing Convictions by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Block Explorer #6
metadata.description:
Block Explorer is a playable piece of generative art.

Created as a collection of unique animated pieces of art with a camera flying through an endless stream of blocks, Block Explorer is also a playful experience pushing the boundaries of interactions in generative art.

How to use :
* Just click to enter the auto art mode.
* Press the space bar to enter the playable mode and take control over the camera. Make your own way and explore as many blocks as you can.
* Press « i » on the home screen to access infos and set a username.


———————
www.ferdinanddervieux.com/BlockExplorer

Block Explorer by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

Dots that make up the image together. They are arranged in boxes of different sizes. And inside them, we are faced with movements from points and it passes over them regardless of the boundaries.
Generative art in p5.js#;,*&

metadata.name: CITYBLOCKS: GENESIS #54
metadata.description:
On desktop, open project in live view and click “S” to download STL file (printable / experimental)
Rotate and zoom with the mouse to explore the model

Cityblocks: Genesis

In the Cityblocks series, urban ensembles are generated with a simple click. With each iteration appears a new densely built city block. Graced with impeccable geometrical lines, devoid of any human presence, these buildings remind us of brutalist utopias like Le Corbusier’s Cité radieuse or Niemeyer’s Brasilia. But despite their clearly modernist feel, there is something hauntingly primitive about them. They could be either New Mexican adobe pueblos, Minoan palaces, or Turkish troglodyte dwellings. Both carved and sculpted, these Ghormenghasts of concrete float in a realm out of time, like in some architect’s dream.

The purpose of this creative work is to generate 3D architectural projects that could be implemented in the real world. The accelerating lives that we live, complicated by growing and unpredictable environmental crises, call for an enhanced capacity to come up quickly with new architectural solutions adapted to different contexts. From computer assisted design to 3D printing, from augmented reality to real-life housing, from sculpture to architecture, this work aims at bridging the gap between the virtual and the tangible.

Working as a visual artist, David Umemoto draws inspiration from his training as an architect. He has been using low-tech methods for a long time, refining his talent for elegant simple shapes and combinatory constructions. Now, poured concrete and home-made moulds are giving way to zero-gravity rotating models. The skills he developed while working with real objects find a new playground in the virtual realm.

metadata.name: Sketch D #89
metadata.description:
Sketch is an open-ended series. Works evolve as I code a generative project, sometimes drastically. Intermediate works usually don't see the light of day - they get archived and forgotten. This series is snapshots of different forms along the way - each standing alone, but also part of a larger meandering work flow. The word Sketch implies incompleteness. This project may end up being two works, or it could evolve for years. Part of the joy of generative art is never knowing what's around the corner. I have no set schedule. There may be multiple Sketches released a week, or it could be weeks or months between drops. I have no idea where Sketch is heading and there is no guarantee of cohesiveness from Sketch to Sketch. Color palettes and forms will change as new ideas are explored.

Sketch D (Disruption). The grid is broken. The color palette from Sketches A, B, and C remains. Most outputs are simply single colors or black and white. Grid size, padding, and colors vary.

Press the spacebar to see the unDisturbed structure.

metadata.name: Shattered Obelisks #202
metadata.description:
Shattered Obelisks began as a work that is dedicated to my habit of mindlessly drawing on paper when I am stressed, depressed or immersed in difficult thoughts.

Like a patient undergoing psychotherapy and piecing together the causes of unconscious fears and anxieties, I and my artwork have assembled ourselves into something shaped, found order in the chaos and separated it from the external noise.

It took 3 months of continuous, obsessive work. I have developed a huge library, designed for hand-like drawing. The functionality of this library is four times larger than what is shown in this drop.

I plan to put this library out into the public domain when I deem it complete, and hope that it will help someone express themselves through the creative process as much as it helped for me.

In case you've encountered a problem with inverted colours, try changing browser or disabling extensions. This problem only occurred once during testing on a massive amount of devices and was resolved by disabling extensions.

IMPORTANT NOTES BLOCK:

NOTE 1: This artwork should be viewed at a browser scale of 100%. Reducing the scale will increase the amount of detail, but may unpredictably affect the preservation of the location of secondary objects.

NOTE 2: This work can be printed on a plotter. Click S for saving it in .SVG.
Detailed instructions and answers to possible questions can be found in the console output of the code.

NOTE 3: This drop is the first one from the series of 3. It will be used as AL ticket in next drops of this series.

@abakshonokoleg
01.08.2022
Tech: P5.JS
License: CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/)

metadata.name: tr4ns4ctions #76
metadata.description:
Tr4ns4ctions is a series of real-time animations that use pixels to create an abstraction of the movement of values. The pixels are constantly rearranging, being transferred from offer to taker, liquify, appear and disappear. They are forming endless compositions, sometimes intransparent or with strange spins.

The level of abstraction has been set to a 2x pixel size and the color palette of the NES with 12 different color modes. 16 pixel patterns serve as the fundamental building blocks and a simplex noise field determines the direction of movement.

click || space => pause/unpause

View all tr4ns4ctions at https://tr4ns4ctions.com

Kim Asendorf, 2022

metadata.name: AN2: Recuerdos  #77
metadata.description:
"AN2: Recuerdos" is an abstract collection that is the direct sequel to Artificialmente Natural. Recuerdos are memories in Spanish, and with this collection, I tried to evoke specifically that, a memory. There are many times throughout our life that our memory changes and grow. Sometimes we even alter memories unconsciously, mixing them up between other memories and even fantasy or dreams (ever had a Deja Vu?), creating a new memory solely based on an idea of the past and what it was. We live in a world of perceptions, and that is exactly what our memory is, a combination of perceptions that became ideas, made up of other older ideas and new ones, to then get stored inside our brain as new memories.

Now, you may ask, cool story, but what does it have to do with the collection? Well, through your memories, experiences, and perceptions, you're going to analyze the piece. You may think you see an abstract ocean in the background, or a sky, or waves, or auras. You may feel that the art piece sometimes looks decayed, splattered with paint, or just splattered with dirty noise. The truth is that through your memory, you're going to try to make sense of it no matter if you like what you're seeing or not, and that's the sole idea of everything. Interpreting through our experiences is how we calm the tension we feel from the unknown. You can't make a comparison or an interpretation if you haven't seen or experienced something that laid an idea inside your brain, becoming multiple other ideas through plasticity and neural connectivity, always trying to make sense of everything. That's why your "recuerdos" is the key to the way you interpret life and live it, both unconsciously and consciously. 

For me, this collection consciously reminds me of my teenage years. A little chaotic at times, with some beautiful moments of self-discovery. Mistakes were made, love was found and lost, and everything was pretty colorful and new. Unconsciously, I don't know, that's the beauty of the unknown. 

--------------------------------------------------------------

NOTICE

Allow list will be deleted 48 hours after the collections goes live.

--------------------------------------------------------------
FYI

Loading of the art goes through 3 stages in order. It may take between 30 seconds to 40 seconds to finalize.

-------------------------------------------------------------

Press [S] to save as PNG

metadata.name: <iframes> #280
metadata.description:
The <iframe> HTML element is an element that allows a web document to embed the contents of another web document within itself. iframes are at the core of fxhash. They are portals opening our view to rich content.

This work is a portal to itself. It loads itself within itself 20 times. It's not pretty, it reminds us of WordArt, it's a little bit hacky, it might break when our tools to display HTML will change. But it's a proof that the limits of our tools are only limits until creativity breaks them.

This work is not purely deterministic, because it simply cannot be. Slight timing differences due to loading times being different each time an <iframe> is loaded will make each visualization slightly unique.

If you view this token on mobile, the nesting limit was reduced to 4 to prevent performance issues.

This work is highly experimental. It leverages a "hack" to allow iframes to be nested.
Firefox max <iframe> nesting depth as of 28/12/2021 is capped at 9.
Works with chrome desktop 96.0.4664.110
